He didn't want to power the whole world for free, he wanted to distribute electricity   this is the ill fated Wardenclyff tower, his plan was to transmit electricity to the whole world, sadly, had we accepted his innovation of wireless electricity, we'd have lived in a better world. and if that tower would have been complete, then he would be able to somehow transmit energy, he couldn't just power the whole world for free, he was going to use the ionosphere and his space age tech so that whenever you needed electricity it showered from the atmosphere and came to your house, i never read anything suggesting wardenclyff tower was linked with it.

No. Of course not. There's this little thing called Conservation of Energy. Power has to come from somewhere. Tesla got downright nutty toward the end of his life. He burned through a lot of money on projects that could never work. And made a lot of wild claims that, unfortunately, modern Conspiracy Theorists dig up and believe.

Tesla described a method of wireless power transmission, he did not as far as I have ever seen actually give a method for free power generation.  His method would actually still require power plants, just not the enormous amount of copper we call the grid today...if it worked. The problem with this system is how to charge money for the power generated, since it is impossible to tell who used the energy.

He did. The problem is: Who on earth would want to invest in such a thing, as there will be no way to know who uses it and how to charge them for it? There would be not much return. No much business involved, as there woud be no need of so much plants and no light poles. It may be of great use in the future (due to coal shortage or pollution) or in some kind of post-capitalist society.
